  • fitlib

fitlib#

Because LMFIT is deficient. fitlib is a glorified wrapper for scipy.optimize.curve_fit. It handles global fitting, complex variables, complex global fitting, and has a handy visualization tool so you can see how close your initial fit parameters were before you start fitting and wasting the time of all those poor electrons.

fit(function, xs, ys, p0, **kwargs)#

The curve_fit wrapper that finds the parameters p1 that minimize the sum of the squared errors of function(xs[i], *p1) - ys[i]

Parameters:

  • function (object) – The name of the function to be fit.

  • xs (iterable[float] or iterable[iterable[float]]) – The x values of the y data. Can be 2D.

  • ys (iterable[float, complex] or iterable[iterable[float, complex]]) – The y values of the data. Can be 2D.

  • p0 – The initial guess of the fit parameters. If there are multiple y iterables (i.e. len(ys) > 1), but one p0 parameter is not an iterable with len() > 1, a global fit will be performed.

Examples:

  • individual fits:

    • len(ys) == 1: p0=[1.0, 1.1, 1.2, 1.3], one value for each parameter

    • len(ys) > 1: p0= [[1.0]*len(ys), [1.1]*len(ys), [1.2]*len(ys), [1.3]*len(ys)] each parameter has same length as ys

  • global fits:

    • len(ys) > 1: p0=[1.0, [1.1]*len(ys), [1.2]*len(ys), [1.3]*len(ys)], at least one parameter be a single value (or an iterable of length(1))

Parameters:

  • guess (int[0, 1] or bool) – A flag indicating whether to plot the fit comparison using the initial p0. Default is 0.

  • check (int[0, 1] or bool) – A flag indicating whether to plot the fit comparison using the final fit parameters p1. Default is 0.

  • result (str or None) – A single string of comma seperate values serving as the label for the displayed fit parameters and result dictionary. Default is p_0, p_1, etc. Example: result=’amplitude, frequency, phase, linewidth’

  • fine (int[0, 1] or bool) – A flag indicating whether to plot guess or check plots with a finer array of x values than the default of the xs values. Default is 0.

  • multi (int) – The number of threads to use when fitting a large number of ys in a non-global fit. Beware Amdahl’s Law: multithreading overhead limits performance gains. Default is 1.

  • logx (int[0, 1] or bool) – A flag indicating if a log scale should be used for the x axis in the guess and check plots. Default is 0.

  • logy (int[0, 1] or bool) – A flag indicating if a log scale should be used for the y axis in the guess and check plots. Default is 0.

  • note (str) – Text to display next to printout of the fit results summary. Default is ‘’.

  • xlabel (str) – Text for the xlabel of the guess and check plots. Default is ‘’.

  • ylabel (str) – Text for the ylabel of the guess and check plots. Default is ‘’.

  • prefix (str) – Text to prepend to the labels of the parameter variable names based on result. Default is ‘’.

  • quiet (int[0, 1] or bool) – A flag to suppress printing results to standard out. Default is 0.

  • suffix (str) – Text to append to the labels of the parameter variable names based on result. Default is ‘’.

  • summary (int[0, 1] or bool) – A flag indicating whether to plot a summary of the fit parameters for calls to fit with len(ys)>1. Default is 0.

  • savefig (str) – If specified, a path, with file extension, of where to save the guess and check figures. Default is ‘’.

  • **kwargs – Other **kwargs recognized by scipy.optimize.curve_fit.

Returns:

The fit parameters and a summary dictionary as p1 and r

Return type:

[p1=ndarray], r=dict]
